newsitem.title: INDIA: Indianoil processes 25.1 mln t in 96/97.
newsitem.headline: Indianoil processes 25.1 mln t in 96/97.

text.p: State-run Indian Oil Corporation (Indianoil) said on Tuesday that its six refineries had processed 25.1 million tonnes of crude oil in fiscal 1996/97 (April-March).
It gave no comparative figure for the previous fiscal year.

Indianoil's six refineries at Guwahati, Barauni, Gujarat, Haldia, Mathura and Digboi together processed 25.1 million tonnes in 1996/97, achieving 102.3 percent capacity utilisation in spite of lower crude oil supplies to Barauni, a comapny statement said.
It said in 1996/97 Indianoil sold 41.74 million tonnes of petroleum products, up from 39.85 million tonnes in the previous year.
During the year the company commissioned a state-of-the-art, 600,000-tonne liquified petroleum gas terminal at Kandla to augment product availability, the statement said.

The statement said Indianoil was expected to complete projects valued at 100 billion rupees ($2.8 billion) during the next two years and had identified several new projects valued at 300 billion rupees.
Major projects likely to be completed during 1997/98 were the Panipat refinery in northern Haryana state and a catalytic reformer at Mathura in Uttar Pradesh state.
The company said during the next two years 25 LPG bottling plants would be set up in phases.

It said the proposed projects include a nine million tonnes grassroot refinery in collaboration with the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation at Paradeep on the east coast and an export-oriented refinery in southern India.
Indianoil said it had entered into an understanding with Britain's Enterprise Oil to jointly develop oilfields.
The statement said its request for allocation of Bombay High offshore fields on nomination basis was awaiting government approval.
The company also intended to participate in deep water exploration projects of Oil and Natural Gas Corp (ONGC), it added.
